**Christopher Cross "Chris" Griffin**[1] is a fictional character from the
American [animated television series](/wiki/Animated_television_series
"Animated television series") _[Family Guy](/wiki/Family_Guy "Family Guy")_.
He is the elder son and middle child of [Peter](/wiki/Peter_Griffin "Peter
Griffin") and [Lois Griffin](/wiki/Lois_Griffin "Lois Griffin") and brother of
[Stewie](/wiki/Stewie_Griffin "Stewie Griffin") and [Meg
Griffin](/wiki/Meg_Griffin "Meg Griffin"). He is voiced by [Seth
Green](/wiki/Seth_Green "Seth Green") and first appeared on television, along
with the rest of the family, in a 15-minute [short](/wiki/Short_film "Short
film") on December 20, 1998. Chris was created and designed by MacFarlane
himself. MacFarlane was asked to pitch a pilot to the [Fox Broadcasting
Company](/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company "Fox Broadcasting Company"), based on
[_The Life of Larry_ and _Larry &
Steve_](/wiki/The_Life_of_Larry_and_Larry_%26_Steve "The Life of Larry and
Larry & Steve"), two shorts made by MacFarlane featuring a middle-aged man
named Larry and an intellectual dog, Steve. After the pilot was given the
green light, the Griffin family appeared in the episode "[Death Has a
Shadow](/wiki/Death_Has_a_Shadow "Death Has a Shadow")".

Originally designed as a somewhat gregarious, yet still unintelligent
teenager, Chris became more awkward and even more idiotic over the course of
the show. Running gags in the series involving Chris include the existence of
an 'Evil Monkey' in his closet (though it is later revealed that [the monkey
is not evil](/wiki/Hannah_Banana "Hannah Banana")), him
[masturbating](/wiki/Masturbation "Masturbation") frequently, and his
pedophile admirer [Herbert](/wiki/Herbert_\(Family_Guy\) "Herbert \(Family
Guy\)").

## Character
origins[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Chris_Griffin&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Character origins")]

Chris' character resembles that of Milt's, the son of the main character Larry
Cummings in _[The Life of Larry](/wiki/Larry_shorts "Larry shorts")_ , one of
the animated short films created by [Seth MacFarlane](/wiki/Seth_MacFarlane
"Seth MacFarlane") at the [Rhode Island School of
Design](/wiki/Rhode_Island_School_of_Design "Rhode Island School of Design")
in 1995 that led to the development of _Family Guy_.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Chris
was originally given a "[punk](/wiki/Punk_rock "Punk rock")" image, according
to creator [Seth MacFarlane](/wiki/Seth_MacFarlane "Seth MacFarlane")'s DVD
commentary tracks. During the first three seasons, he wore gold earrings, and
his painful awkwardness was not as emphasized as it was supposed to be in the
series, as he has now slowly become more gregarious.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## Personality[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Chris_Griffin&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Personality")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) |  This section **does not[cite](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources") any [sources](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Please help [improve this section](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Chris_Griffin&action=edit) by [adding citations to reliable sources](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1 "Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1"). Unsourced material may be challenged and [removed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Burden_of_evidence "Wikipedia:Verifiability"). _(December 2017)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
Chris is an overweight, idealistic, outgoing, and good-hearted teenage boy.
But aside from that, Chris deals with problems that any other pubescent boy
would face: [acne](/wiki/Acne "Acne"), girls, and school. On the Volume 1 DVD
Boxset TV guides special _Family Guy_ edition, it stated that Chris "wouldn't
hurt a fly, unless it landed on his hot dog". Due to Chris' weight, he was
referred to as an "Elephant Child" when he was born. In one episode as Chris
runs away from his pedophile admirer, [Herbert](/wiki/Herbert_\(Family_Guy\)
"Herbert \(Family Guy\)"), Herbert murmers to himself, "Get your fat ass back
here!"

Chris is more often than not willing to take drastic measures to get what he
wants or needs, particularly when it comes to keeping up with his grades in
school. He once believed that he got a bad grade on a mathematics test when he
tickled his brain by sticking an army man's rifle into his nose and
accidentally puncturing a lobe. Fortunately, he is more well-endowed than
Peter is, as he has a variety of talents, such as [drawing](/wiki/Drawing
"Drawing"), [filmmaking](/wiki/Filmmaking "Filmmaking"), [video
editing](/wiki/Video_editing "Video editing"), playing sports at school, etc.
He also has an encyclopedic knowledge of [pop culture](/wiki/Pop_culture "Pop
culture"), as well as films, television series, actors and actresses, tropes,
making a film good or bad, etc. Generally, Chris is a fast learner; in
"[Patriot Games](/wiki/Patriot_Games_\(Family_Guy\) "Patriot Games \(Family
Guy\)")", when the family moved to [London](/wiki/London "London"), Chris was
the only member of the family who learned how to speak [cockney
English](/wiki/Cockney_English "Cockney English") in a matter of seconds.

Despite this, Chris can be naive, often to the point of having a tendency to
get away with things. In "[Lethal Weapons](/wiki/Lethal_Weapons "Lethal
Weapons")", when Peter and Lois were having a fist fight, Chris cheered for
[Peter](/wiki/Peter_Griffin "Peter Griffin"), telling him to "kick her ass!";
earlier in the episode, after Chris breaks a vase with his basketball and Lois
tells Peter to punish him, Peter tells him to "punish himself" and
subsequently [spanks](/wiki/Corporal_punishment "Corporal punishment")
himself. Also, in _Stewie Griffin: The Untold Story_ , when the children watch
Lois and Peter are trying to make out, Chris mistakes it for a fight and says,
"I don't know what they're fighting about, Meg, but I think Dad's winning. Go
Dad!" In the episode "[Trading Places](/wiki/Trading_Places_\(Family_Guy\)
"Trading Places \(Family Guy\)")", after Chris accidentally damages Peter's
[dirt bike](/wiki/Dirt_bike "Dirt bike"), Peter "punishes" him by making him
[start smoking](/wiki/Tobacco_smoking "Tobacco smoking").

For most of the series, Chris is more socially active at school than Meg is,
having various friends, both of which are boys and girls, whilst attending
Buddy Cianci Junior High School (later James Woods Regional High School). Not
surprisingly, as the series progressed and Meg became more often seen with her
group of friends, Chris' social status was boosted to the point of being
friends with everyone at James Woods Regional High School.[_[episode
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_] In [Stew-
Roids](/wiki/Stew-Roids "Stew-Roids"), the school's [queen
bee](/wiki/Queen_bee "Queen bee") Connie D'Amico dates Chris, at first to be
more popular because of "dating a loser", but begins to see Chris as he really
is after he says he likes her as well. Later in the episode however, she dumps
him after making out with two other boys at a house party, but everyone takes
pity on Chris and shuns Connie. Angry at Chris for usurping her place on the
school's "social ladder", she attempts to humiliate Chris by tricking [Neil
Goldman](/wiki/Neil_Goldman "Neil Goldman") into showing the students a video
of him re-enacting a scene from the [Silence of the
Lambs](/wiki/The_Silence_of_the_Lambs_\(film\) "The Silence of the Lambs
\(film\)") where Buffalo Bill dances nude in front of a mirror, but Meg and
Chris's friends manage to stop her. Afterwards, Chris makes a speech over the
PA system about what it is like to be popular, and then says "man, it's hard
work being this shallow". In ["Once Bitten"](/wiki/Once_Bitten_\(Family_Guy\)
"Once Bitten \(Family Guy\)"), Chris becomes friends with [Neil
Goldman](/wiki/List_of_characters_in_Family_Guy#Neil_Goldman "List of
characters in Family Guy"), the resident nerd who is Meg's self-proclaimed
love interest. Although their friendship was initially a ploy for Neil to get
closer to Meg, Neil feels bad for using Chris and returns to him to resume
their newfound friendship.

## Evil Monkey[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Chris_Griffin&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Evil Monkey")]

In a [running gag](/wiki/Running_gag "Running gag"), starting in the episode
"[Dammit Janet!](/wiki/Dammit_Janet! "Dammit Janet!")," Chris is regularly
tormented by an [evil monkey](/wiki/Evil_Monkey "Evil Monkey") who lives in
his closet, though whenever he complains about it to anyone, they (a reference
to the iconic tale of the [Boy Who Cried Wolf](/wiki/Boy_Who_Cried_Wolf "Boy
Who Cried Wolf")) often laugh along with him instead thinking it is a joke,
after which the monkey appears with a malevolent grimace and points at Chris
in a threatening manner. In "[Hannah Banana](/wiki/Hannah_Banana "Hannah
Banana")", Chris proves the monkey's part in the show to the family, and even
ends up becoming friends with him after the monkey (who appears not to be evil
at all, but just a poor creature who was depressed after his ex-wife cheated
on him with another monkey) helps him write out a book report and pass. The
simian explains his frightening mannerisms as a result of various conditions
and unintended actions. Chris introduces him to his friends, hang out with
each other in fun places, and the monkey helps Chris in his studies in school,
which Peter does not do. This, however, causes a rift between Chris and Peter
when Chris realizes that the monkey cares more for him than his father.
Eventually the monkey helps the two patch things up, especially after Peter
saves the monkey from [Miley Cyrus](/wiki/Miley_Cyrus "Miley Cyrus") (who is
depicted as an [android](/wiki/Android_\(robot\) "Android \(robot\)")) who had
kidnapped him à la _[King Kong](/wiki/King_Kong_\(2005_film\) "King Kong
\(2005 film\)")_. After that, the monkey happily moves out of Chris' closet to
live in the closet of Tom Tucker's son Jake, where the cycle will start in a
new beginning, as Jake himself experiences difficulty with his father.

In a 2003 interview, Seth MacFarlane stated that the writers thought it would
be funny to give Chris a childhood fear that is actually real, since he has "a
childlike mind".[2] The monkey's trademark grimace and pointing was the idea
of writer [Mike Barker](/wiki/Mike_Barker_\(producer\) "Mike Barker
\(producer\)").[2]

## Identification with Seth
Green[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Chris_Griffin&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Identification with Seth Green")]

Another [running gag](/wiki/Running_gag "Running gag"), starting in the _[Star
Wars](/wiki/Star_Wars "Star Wars")_ remake episode "[Blue
Harvest](/wiki/Blue_Harvest_\(Family_Guy\) "Blue Harvest \(Family Guy\)")",
has Chris defending _[Robot Chicken](/wiki/Robot_Chicken "Robot Chicken")_ , a
show created by portrayer Seth Green which is broadcast on the [Adult
Swim](/wiki/Adult_Swim "Adult Swim") block on the [Cartoon
Network](/wiki/Cartoon_Network "Cartoon Network") cable network. When Peter
(_Family Guy_ creator Seth MacFarlane) denigrates that show in "Blue Harvest",
Chris loses his temper and storms off. Carried on in "[Something, Something,
Something, Dark Side](/wiki/Something,_Something,_Something,_Dark_Side
"Something, Something, Something, Dark Side")", though Chris attempts to keep
a cool head, he storms off again when Peter offers to tell the story of
_[Without a Paddle](/wiki/Without_a_Paddle "Without a Paddle")_ , a critically
panned film that features Seth Green. Both these scenes happen in the [framing
device](/wiki/Framing_device "Framing device") of the episode and not in the
interior _Star Wars_ narrative, in which Green portrays Chris as _Star Wars_
hero [Luke Skywalker](/wiki/Luke_Skywalker "Luke Skywalker"). In the final
_Star Wars_ parody, "[It's a Trap!](/wiki/It%27s_a_Trap! "It's a Trap!")",
mocking Green's career provokes further anger in Chris; Chris tries to defend
Green by citing _[Buffy the Vampire
Slayer](/wiki/Buffy_the_Vampire_Slayer_\(TV_series\) "Buffy the Vampire Slayer
\(TV series\)")_ as an example of a success in Green's career, but Carter
Pewterschmidt suggests that the popularity of _Buffy_ had been largely over-
stated by _[Entertainment Weekly](/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly "Entertainment
Weekly")_. These taunts give Chris—in character as Skywalker—the conviction to
fight back against Stewie/[Darth Vader](/wiki/Darth_Vader "Darth Vader") and
Carter/[Darth Sidious](/wiki/Darth_Sidious "Darth Sidious") (both played by
MacFarlane). In the closing scenes of the episode's framing device, Chris gets
to reverse the joke by poking fun at Seth MacFarlane's career, going so far as
to suggest that _Family Guy_ is a rip-off of _[The
Simpsons](/wiki/The_Simpsons "The Simpsons")_ ; MacFarlane is, however,
defended by the characters whom he voices (Peter, Brian and Stewie).

Outside of the _Star Wars_ -themed episodes, "[Road to the
Multiverse](/wiki/Road_to_the_Multiverse "Road to the Multiverse")" plays on
the running gag, but with Stewie (MacFarlane once more) provoking the _[Robot
Chicken](/wiki/Robot_Chicken "Robot Chicken")_ Universe counterpart of Chris
by asking "How does it feel to be on a major network for thirty seconds?"
which prompts Chris to say "Fuck you!".

## Appearance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Chris_Griffin&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Appearance")]

Chris is the only Griffin family member to have blond hair, which is odd
considering that Peter has brown hair and Lois has orange hair. He, like Meg,
wears a signature hat, an orange and black baseball cap, and dresses in a blue
T-shirt, black pants, and white hi-top sneakers with red stripes. In several
of the early episodes, he, along with Lois, has had his ears pierced and wore
gold earrings.
